    • Field Detail

      • level

        public static int level
        The level of difficulty for the user. (Set throughout game)

    • Constructor Detail

      • Board

        public Board()
        For each square in the board layout, set it as unselected. This is to ensure that the user has a fresh board whenever we create an instance of a class.

    • Method Detail

      • getBoardLayout

        public bp.Square[] getBoardLayout()
        Getting the board layout for the current board. This will return the board layout for the current instance of this class.
        Returns:
        boardLayout The layout of the board

      • setBoardLayout

        public void setBoardLayout(bp.Square[] pboardLayout)
        Setting the layout of the board given an array.
        Parameters:
        pboardLayout - The given layout of the board

      • setBoardSquare

        public void setBoardSquare(int psquareIndex,
                           bp.Square pvalueToSet)
        Setting the board given an index value and a value to set.
        Parameters:
        psquareIndex - The index value of the square to set a value for.
        pvalueToSet - The value that we are setting this square to.

      • getBoardSquare

        public bp.Square getBoardSquare(int psquareIndex)
        Retrieving the layout of the board.
        Parameters:
        psquareIndex - The index of the square we are returning
        Returns:
        boardLayout The layout of the specified square

      • isOccupied

        public boolean isOccupied(int psquareIndex)
        Checking if a square is occupied at any given index value. This is checked by seeing if a square has not been set to the enum "Unselected".
        Parameters:
        psquareIndex - The index of the square we're checking
        Returns:
        True if the square is occupied, false if the square isn't

      • isXTurn

        public boolean isXTurn()
        Checking to see if it is X's turn. This is done by looking at the boolean, and what the value is currently set to. Since this boolean is set every move, this provides an accurate way to describe whose turn it is.
        Returns:
        True is it is X's turn, false if it is not

      • isTieGame

        public boolean isTieGame()
        Checking if the game is tied. Automatically set the tie true, unless we can find a spot that is not occupied. In which case, we don't have a tie since the game has not even finished. If we can't find a square that isn't occupied, then we'll return this to be a tie if this is a tie, and the game has not been won.
        Returns:
        True if the game is tied, false otherwise

      • setXTurn

        public void setXTurn(boolean pxTurn)
        Setting the "xturn" value based on what is passed in. For this boolean, if it's true, that means that it is X's turn. If it's false, that means it's O's turn.
        Parameters:
        pxTurn - Boolean value if it is X's turn

      • getPlayerValue

        public bp.Square getPlayerValue()
        Getting the player's value. This is done by returning the "playerValue" String, which was set at the beginning of the game.
        Returns:
        "O" if the player is "O", "X" if the player is "X"

      • setPlayerValue

        public void setPlayerValue(bp.Square pplayerValue)
        Setting the value of the player. This is setting the String "playerValue" to describe if the player is X or O.
        Parameters:
        pplayerValue - "X" if the player is "X", "O" if the player is "O"

      • getWinner

        public java.lang.String getWinner()
        Getting the winner of the game. This is done by retrieving the "winner" String, which is set when we have a winner to a particular game.
        Returns:
        X/O Depending on who won

      • setWinner

        public void setWinner(java.lang.String pwinner)
        Setting the winner of the game. Setting the String "winner" to describe who won the game.
        Parameters:
        pwinner - The winner of the game

      • setLevel

        public void setLevel(int plevel)
        Setting the level of difficulty for the game. This is done by setting the static integer "level" to let every class know which level of difficulty the user is on.
        Parameters:
        plevel - The difficult level for the game

      • getLevel

        public int getLevel()
        Getting the level of difficulty of the current game. We do this by retrieving the static integer "level" from the Board class.
        Returns:
        level The level of difficulty of the game

      • isGameWon

        public boolean isGameWon()
        Figuring if the current game has been won or not. This is an overloaded method that refers to the "isGameWon" boolean method to figure this out.
        Returns:
        True if the game has been won, false if it hasn't.

      • isGameWon

        public boolean isGameWon(bp.Square[] boardToCheck)
        Checking to see if the game has been won. This is done by checking half of the perimeter of the board and using array manipulation to check if the column, rows, or diagonals all match in value and are non-empty.
        Parameters:
        boardToCheck - The board that is currently in play
        Returns:
        A boolean value contingent upon if the game has been won

      • randomNum

        public static int randomNum(int min,
                            int max)
        Generating a random number. This is done by figuring the difference between the maximum and minimum, adding one, and summing this with the minimum value.
        Parameters:
        min - The minimum value to choose from
        max - The maximum value to choose from
        Returns:
        The value that we've randomly picked from

      • getAiMove

        public int getAiMove(int level)
        Getting the computer's move depending on the current level of difficulty. For level 0, we pick random index value for the computer to play. For level 1, we see if we can win and place our index there, otherwise, we pick random values. For level 2, we see if we can win. If we can't, we look if the user can win. If the user can win, we block them by setting out index value to that position.
        Parameters:
        level - The current level of difficulty
        Returns:
        The index value of the computer's move

      • getNumberOfEmptySquares

        public final int getNumberOfEmptySquares()
        Getting the number of empty squares at any given time.
        Returns:
        numOfEmp The number of empty squares on the board

      • getEmptySquareIndices

        public final java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getEmptySquareIndices()
        Getting the index values of all the empty squares at any given time.
        Returns:
        emptySquare The array of index values corresponding to the squares that are empty.

      • getUserWinningMoveIndexForCurrentTurn

        public int getUserWinningMoveIndexForCurrentTurn(bp.Square[] boardToCheck)
        Getting the user's winning move for our opponent. This is done by theoretically placing an "X" or an "O" (whichever our opponent is playing) and calling our "isGameWon" method to determine if our opponent could win at that given index value we placed our pseudo "X" or "O" in. If we can find such an index value such that this is the case, return that index value...because the user can play that position and win in their next turn. Otherwise, return -1.
        Parameters:
        boardToCheck - The board that the user is currently playing
        Returns:
        The index value for our opponent to win

      • isAiTurn

        public boolean isAiTurn()
        Checking to see if it is the computer's turn.
        Returns:
        boolean True if is it the computer's turn, false otherwise

      • getImmediateWinningMoveIndexForCurrentTurn

        public int getImmediateWinningMoveIndexForCurrentTurn(bp.Square[] boardToCheck)
        Retrieving the winning move for the current turn we're on. This is done by theoretically placing an "X" or an "O" (whichever the current turn is on) and calling out "isGameWon" method to check if we could win at that position. If we can find such an index value, return that index. Otherwise, return -1.
        Parameters:
        boardToCheck - The board that we're currently playing
        Returns:
        The index value for us to play to win

      • getAiPlayerValue

        public bp.Square getAiPlayerValue()
        Getting the AI's player value.
        Returns:
        aiPlayerValue Either X/O, depending on what the computer is

      • setAiPlayerValue

        public void setAiPlayerValue(bp.Square aiPlayerValue)
        Setting the computer's value.
        Parameters:
        aiPlayerValue - Either X/O, depending on what the computer is

      • getHumanPlayerValue

        public bp.Square getHumanPlayerValue()
        Retrieving the value (either X/O) of what the human token is.
        Returns:
        humanPlayerValue The value of the human token

      • setHumanPlayerValue

        public void setHumanPlayerValue(bp.Square humanPlayerValue)
        Setting the value of the human token.
        Parameters:
        humanPlayerValue - The value of the human token (X/O)
